solution_line_template: If he babysits for {babysitting_hours} hours at ${babysitting_rate} per hour, he will earn {babysitting_hours}*{babysitting_rate} = $<<{babysitting_hours}*{babysitting_rate}={babysitting_earnings}>>{babysitting_earnings}

This week he will earn ${weekly_allowance} allowance, ${lawn_mowing_pay} mowing the lawn and ${babysitting_earnings} from babysitting for a total of {weekly_allowance}+{lawn_mowing_pay}+{babysitting_earnings} = $<<{weekly_allowance}+{lawn_mowing_pay}+{babysitting_earnings}={total_earnings_this_week}>>{total_earnings_this_week}

If we add the ${total_earnings_this_week} he will earn to his ${initial_savings} savings, he will have a total of {total_earnings_this_week} + {initial_savings} = $<<{total_earnings_this_week}+{initial_savings}={total_money_after_earnings}>>{total_money_after_earnings}

The bike costs ${bike_cost} and he will have ${total_money_after_earnings} leaving ${bike_cost}-${total_money_after_earnings} = $<<{bike_cost}-{total_money_after_earnings}={money_needed}>>{money_needed} more that he will need to earn
